quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 14 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 14.4: Solving Systems Using Inverse Matrices
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Using the matrix equation AX = B

questions.question: Given the system $2x + 3y = 5$ and $x - 2y = 4$, what is the coefficient matrix $A$?
questions.explanation: The coefficient matrix $A$ is formed by taking the coefficients of the variables $x$ and $y$ in order from each equation.

questions.question: If $AX = B$, which expression correctly solves for the variable matrix $X$?
questions.explanation: Because matrix multiplication is not commutative, you must multiply by $A^{-1}$ on the left of both sides to correctly isolate $X$.

questions.question: What must be true about the coefficient matrix $A$ to solve a system using the inverse matrix method?
options: The determinant of $A$ must not be zero.
The constants in matrix $B$ must be positive.
Matrix $A$ must be a zero matrix.
questions.explanation: If the determinant is zero, the matrix is singular and has no inverse, meaning this specific method cannot be used to find a unique solution.

questions.question: In the matrix equation $AX = B$, what does the matrix $X$ usually represent?
options: A column matrix of the variables, such as $\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}$.
The solution values for the constants.
questions.explanation: Matrix $X$ is the 'variable matrix,' which stores the unknowns we are trying to solve for.

questions.question: Solve the system using matrices: $x + y = 5$ and $x - y = 1$. If $A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5 & 0.5 \\ 0.5 & -0.5 \end{bmatrix}$, what is $X$?
What is the dimension of the constant matrix $B$ for a system of 3 equations with 3 variables?
questions.explanation: Matrix $B$ is a column matrix containing the constant from each of the 3 equations, making it a $3 \times 1$ matrix.

questions.question: If a $2 \times 2$ system of equations represents two parallel lines, what will be the determinant of the coefficient matrix?
questions.explanation: Parallel lines mean the system has no solution (or is dependent). In either case, the coefficient matrix will be singular, meaning its determinant is 0.

questions.question: When setting up $AX = B$, how should the equations be organized?
options: Variables must be in the same order in every equation, with constants on the right.
Constants must be on the left with the variables.
The equations can be in any order or format.
Only one variable can be on the left side.
questions.explanation: Standard form ($ax + by = c$) is required to ensure the coefficients align correctly within the matrix $A$.

questions.question: If $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 10 \end{bmatrix}$, what is the solution for $X$?
questions.explanation: Since $A$ is the Identity Matrix, its inverse is also the Identity Matrix. $X = IB = B$.

questions.question: Why is the matrix method $X = A^{-1}B$ often preferred in computer science over manual elimination?
options: It allows for solving systems with hundreds of variables efficiently using algorithms.
It is the only way to solve nonlinear equations.
It always results in whole numbers.
questions.explanation: Matrix operations are highly optimized for computer processors, making them the standard for large-scale data calculations.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You can translate and solve systems using matrix equations.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Remember that $A$ must be on the left side of $B$ when multiplying by the inverse.
scoreMessages.50: Practice setting up the $AX = B$ form from a set of linear equations.
scoreMessages.0: Review how to multiply a $2 \times 2$ matrix by a $2 \times 1$ column matrix.
